title: Worked example
text: can install spmapper directly within R (recommended) code, via download github repository, linked via “Download spmapper” box homepage website.
code: # Install spmapper from within R  library(devtools) devtools::install_github("NERC-CEH/spmapper-pkg")   ## If you have downloaded the package files directly from the github repository,  you will first need to install the package by modifying the below example code # install.packages("C:/Users/myusername/Downloads/spmapper-pkg_[0.1.0].tar.gz", repos = NULL, type = "source") # with the correct file path and version name etc  # load the package library(spmapper)

title: Worked example
text: Load packages needed tool functions. Check necessary packages installed.
code: # load required packages library(spmapper) library(terra)  library(sf) library(knitr) library(rnaturalearth) library(viridis) library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) ## Define tool directory path - this is important to source the package functions, and for those functions to locate the input data! tooldir <- system.file("extdata", package = "spmapper") # automatically find and define your file path - but do check the path is correct  # tooldir <- file.path(".../spmapper") # alternatively, modify here to your package files directory if you have installed the package elsewhere # Load package functions invisible(system.file("R", "functions_preymodel.R", package = "spmapper")) invisible(system.file("R", "functions_spmapper.R", package = "spmapper")) invisible(system.file("R", "functions_fpudoverlap.R", package = "spmapper")) invisible(system.file("R", "functions_spmapplot.R", package = "spmapper"))

title: Worked example
text: Users can specify multiple polygon/multipolygon objects apply rest example code compare prey consumption across areas. spmapper functions capable handling multipolygon objects. Users reminded define Coordinate Reference System (CRS) loaded shapefiles. spmapper reprojects user polygons align prey consumption maps. spmapper includes function plot prey consumption maps user polygons overlaid (see ).
code: # Specify shapefile/s fppolys <- sf::st_read(file.path()) # Add your filepath/s here.   ## Users must define the CRS of their loaded shapefile for spmapper to function! fppolys <- st_crs([...]) # define source file CRS

title: Worked example
text: UK offshore wind farm footprints ‘production’, ‘planned’, ‘construction’ ‘approved’ statuses, collated European Marine Observation Data Network (via EMODnet; CETMAR, 2024). Offshore electricity transmission (OFTO) polygons excluded.

what: Run primary function spmapper()  - produces prey consumption maps for chosen species and optionally extracts quantities within user-specified polygons, if provided.
title: Worked example
text: Specify species interest “spname =”, optional user-supplied polygons “fppolys =”, directory tool data “tooldir =” (defined earlier ‘Load packages functions’). object returned (e.g. out_kitt) list object various inputs, quantities, output prey consumption maps.
code: out_kitt <- spmapper(spname = "Kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = tooldir)  out_cogu <- spmapper(spname = "Guillemot", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = tooldir)  out_razo <- spmapper(spname = "Razorbill", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = tooldir)

what: Visualise prey consumption maps with optional input polygons overlaid, using spmapplot()
title: Worked example
text: spmapplot() takes two arguments, first prey consumption map (raster, generated spmapper(), contained list outputs form out_kitt$prey_cons_map), second optional argument polygon object (e.g. user’s polygons, fppolys)
code: # Plot all species prey consumption maps  (spmapplot(out_kitt$prey_cons_map, fppolys) + ggtitle("Kittiwake")) + (spmapplot(out_cogu$prey_cons_map, fppolys) + ggtitle("Guillemot")) + (spmapplot(out_razo$prey_cons_map, fppolys) + ggtitle("Razorbill")) +    patchwork::plot_layout(ncol = 1) # Or plot a single species map, e.g. Razorbill spmapplot(out_razo$prey_cons_map, fppolys) + ggtitle("Razorbill")

title: Worked example
text: following code plots distribution prey mass estimates produced spmapper(), annotates baseline estimate dashed line.
code: blki_p <- ggplot(data.frame(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim), aes(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim/1000)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 50, color = "gray10", fill = "skyblue") +   geom_vline(xintercept = out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est/1000, color = "gray10", linetype = "longdash", linewidth = 1.1) +   labs(x = "Prey consumption mass, t", y = "Frequency", title = "Kittiwake") +   theme_minimal()  cogu_p <- ggplot(data.frame(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim), aes(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim/1000)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 50, color = "gray10", fill = "skyblue") +   geom_vline(xintercept = out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est/1000, color = "gray10", linetype = "longdash", linewidth = 1.1) +   labs(x = "Prey consumption mass, t", y = "Frequency", title = "Guillemot") +   theme_minimal()  razo_p <- ggplot(data.frame(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim), aes(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim/1000)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 50, color = "gray10", fill = "skyblue") +   geom_vline(xintercept = out_razo$allbirds_prey_est/1000, color = "gray10", linetype = "longdash", linewidth = 1.1) +   labs(x = "Prey consumption mass, t", y = "Frequency", title = "Razorbill") +   theme_minimal()  (blki_p + cogu_p + razo_p)

title: Worked example
text: folowing code produces table prey mass consumption (kg) estimates species. Estimate refers baseline estimate, CI_Lower lower confidence interval (2.5%) CI_Upper upper confidence interval (97.5%). Prey consumption mass, kg
code: tab_kitt <- data.frame(   Species = "Kittiwake",   Estimate = out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est,    CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_cogu <- data.frame(   Species = "Guillemot",   Estimate = out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est,    CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_razo <- data.frame(   Species = "Razorbill",   Estimate = out_razo$allbirds_prey_est,    CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  kable(rbind(tab_kitt, tab_cogu, tab_razo), digits = 2, caption = "Prey consumption mass, kg")

title: Worked example
text: following code produces table results spatial extraction prey consumption within polygons. fp_percent percentage total prey consumption, fp_Estimate baseline prey mass (kg), fp_CI_Lower lower confidence interval prey mass (kg, 2.5%), fp_CI_Upper upper confidence interval prey mass (kg, 97.5%) contained within polygons. Polygon extraction results
code: fp_tab_kitt <- data.frame(   Species = "Kittiwake",   fp_percent = round(out_kitt$fp_ud_overlap * 100, 4), # % prey consumption in footprint/s, 4 d.p.   fp_Estimate = out_kitt$allbirds_prey_fp_est,    fp_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.025)), # 2.5%   fp_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.975))) # 97.5%  fp_tab_cogu <- data.frame(   Species = "Guillemot",   fp_percent = round(out_cogu$fp_ud_overlap * 100, 4), # % prey consumption in footprint/s, 4 d.p.   fp_Estimate = out_cogu$allbirds_prey_fp_est,    fp_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.025)), # 2.5%   fp_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.975))) # 97.5%  fp_tab_razo <- data.frame(   Species = "Razorbill",   fp_percent = round(out_razo$fp_ud_overlap * 100, 4), # % prey consumption in footprint/s, 4 d.p.   fp_Estimate = out_razo$allbirds_prey_fp_est,    fp_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.025)), # 2.5%   fp_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_fp_sim, 0.975))) # 97.5%  kable(rbind(fp_tab_kitt, fp_tab_cogu, fp_tab_razo), digits=1, caption = "Polygon extraction results")

title: Worked example
text: spmapper performs checks potential input specification errors. following examples illustrate error messages produced cases mis-specification.

title: Worked example
text: spmapper explicitly checks whether provided species names valid (including capitalisation).
code: spmapper(spname = "kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = tooldir) ## Error in spmapper(spname = "kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = tooldir): Invalid species name: must be 'Kittiwake', 'Guillemot' or 'Razorbill'!

title: Worked example
text: spmapper currently explicitly check path provided correct/valid, may yield sensible error messages incorrect path specified.
code: spmapper(spname = "Kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, tooldir = "test") ## Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file 'test/fame_population_ests.csv': ## No such file or directory ## Error in file(file, "rt"): cannot open the connection

title: Worked example
text: tool check directly validity polygons provided, run three checks consistency polygons prey consumption maps. spmapplot() can used visualise polygons overlaid prey consumption maps.

title: Worked example
code: ## Error in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Size of footprint is smaller than the size of a single grid cell - tool would not produce meaningful results in this situation

code: ## Error in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Polygon lies partly or completely outside area of selected grid!

what: The consequences of developing in areas evaluated using spmapper are not indicated.
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: spmapper outputs indicate displacement rates demographic impacts, .e. much indicated prey consumption lost seabirds input area developed, subsequent impacts breeding performance via energetic effects. emphasise use spmapper comparative tool candidate areas development protective measures.

what: Uncertainty in prey intake mass estimates
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: spmapper provides expected range (95% intervals) prey mass intake seabird species network chick-rearing adults, representing uncertainty prey mass consumption estimates. Uncertainty estimates concern prey masses , proportions consumption. Spatial estimations prey consumption (.e. underlying utilisation distributions) fixed proportional estimates space use. Therefore, variation uncertainty spatial component assumed; e.g. arising inter-annual variation space use uncertainty relationships used within predictive spatial models (Wakefield et al., 2017).

what: Prey consumption estimates are derived from a provided baseline dataset
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: Values parameters underpin estimates prey consumption masses provided baseline , relevant, correspond time period Future Atlantic Marine Environment (FAME) seabird tracking study period (2010-2014) align space use estimates available UK & Ireland scale (Wakefield et al. 2017). Intake model parameters sources published dataset (Leedham et al. 2025). Note, mass change (parameter: mass_change) Razorbill assumed equivalent Guillemot (Leedham et al. 2025) due lack empirical data species. See supporting documentation Leedham et al. (2025) dataset full description data sourcing.

what: Modifying input parameters may impact prey mass estimates.
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: Users may modify input parameters prey intake model, users must indicate changes use spmapper outputs, full explanation changes defaults.

what: Use of spmapper at the appropriate spatial scale
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: spmapper concerns space use broad, shelf-seas scale, seabird species networks UK Ireland. spmapper generates prey consumption maps regular 2x2 km grid, Lambert azimuthal equal-area projection. Users provide polygons footprint shapefiles smaller single grid cell spmapper extract. spmapper() function return warning polygon insufficient size (.e. smaller single grid cell) provided. Note, population scale mass consumption estimated UK & Ireland combined seabird species networks correspond GPS tracking underpinning utilisation distributions (Wakefield et al., 2017). Extractions within supplied polygons therefore provide proportion prey mass taken UK & Ireland seabirds, due central place foraging breeding colonies, extractions within polygons retrieve prey masses taken breeding seabirds colonies within foraging range distances. Note, spmapper recommended use comparative tool (see ).

what: Seabird space use may vary through time
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: evidence seabirds given colony can use marine space quite differently across years (paper prep). Understanding drivers variation challenging, patterns may indicate potential consequences development protection given area (.e. level individual developments protection areas) may vary year year. , spatial extractions appropriate assess spatial prey consumption colony level. broader spatial scale used spmapper, apply utilisation distributions provide representative, predicted distribution marine space use species. space use estimates derived models predict space use based GPS tracking data. predicted use marine space species modelled according environmental spatial characteristics, including distance colonies suitability habitat (see Wakefield et al., 2017 details space use modelling). spmapper include potential inter-annual variation prey mass consumption, can substantial level individual colonies (paper prep).

what: Windfarms may alter the quantity and distribution of prey available to seabirds.
title: Recommendations, Caveats & Limitations
text: realised impacts OWFs seabird foraging dynamics energetics may also depend responses prey OWFs OWF-mediated changes geophyisical biological processes. spmapper assume prey redistribution altered productivity dynamics post-OWF areas within protected areas.

(2025) “Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake”, NERC EDS Environmental Information Data Centre. https://doi.org/10.5285/07b1105a-4a14-47e3-b491-9af59be90aff Wakefield, E. D., Owen, E., Baer, J., Carroll, M. J., Daunt, F., Dodd, S. G., Green, J. ., Guilford, T., Mavor, R. ., Miller, P. ., Newell, M. ., Newton, S. F., Robertson, G. S., Shoji, ., Soanes, L. title: Methods
text: spmapper estimates, uncertainty, total prey consumed course chick-rearing period typical breeding adult bird focal species. estimates scaled give fish prey mass intake entire breeding population. Utilisation distributions used estimate spatial origin prey mass waters surrounding UK & Ireland. providing spatial polygons, users can interrogate resulting prey consumption maps indicate foraging value marine spatial areas breeding seabirds. underlying calculations follow following stages: 1) Estimate prey mass intake single breeding adult 2) Scale individual prey mass intake species network breeding population 3) Map spatial distribution prey consumption 4) Extraction absolute & proportional prey mass within areas interest Values underlying key behavioural energetic parameters available dataset (Leedham et al., 2025); sourcing calculation methods described full supporting documentation.

what: 1) Estimate prey mass intake by a single breeding adult
title: Methods
text: estimate mass fish prey taken single adult across full chick-rearing period, developed model considers key behavioural, energetic ecological traits typical adult species. Firstly, estimate daily energetic requirements (DER) adult, consists individual’s energetic demands, half share daily chick requirements, multiplied average number chicks per nest. Adult DER equal mean cost activity costs, weighted proportion time per day allocated core behaviours (foraging, flight, rest--sea & rest nest), addition nominal daily cost warming prey loads body temperature. Total energetic requirement per adult full chick-rearing period calculated DER multiplied species-specific chick-rearing durations (days). breeding adults typically lose mass rearing chicks, realised energy intake fish prey taken single adult across chick rearing period seasonal energy requirement minus energy provided metabolised body tissue. energy quotient calculated mass typical breeding adult, multiplied proportional change body mass across breeding season (give intermediate value absolute body mass change), multiplied energy density seabird body tissue. realised seasonal energy intake converted prey mass intake dividing product prey energy density, species’ digestive energy efficiency. described calculation applied sets species parameter values (Leedham et al., 2025) giving baseline prey mass estimates species. Additionally, prey mass intake calculation applied 60 thousand sets parameter values per species (datasets provided) randomly sampled continuous probability distributions parameter (paper prep). calculations provide uncertainty prey mass estimates (2.5th 97.5th percentiles). Time-activity budgets simulated using Markov chain Montecarlo (MCMC) sampling. parameters drawn probability distributions mean values.

what: 2) Scale individual prey mass intake to the species network breeding population
title: Methods
text: total prey mass taken breeding adults given species network individual, seasonal prey mass intake, multiplied estimates number breeding adults. UDs correspond tracking seabirds across UK & Ireland (see ; Wakefield et al., 2017), individual intake quantities scaled estimates UK & Ireland species network breeding population sizes time period corresponding GPS tracking (2010-2014). estimated breeding sizes scaling species’ breeding counts Seabird2000 full national census (Mitchell et al., 2004), change ratios derived subset colony recounts available 2010-2014 via Seabird Monitoring Programme (SMP; app.bto.org/seabirds/public). spmapper currently include uncertainty population size.

what: 3) Map the spatial distribution of prey consumption
title: Methods
text: spatial origin prey mass consumption derived multiplying prey quantities utilisation distributions (UDs), maps proportional use marine space species. UK & Ireland scale UDs focal species produced RSPB (GPS sampling quantitative methods, see Wakefield et al., 2017).

what: 4) Extraction of absolute & proportional prey mass within areas of interest
title: Methods
text: proportion species’ breeding population’s prey consumption contained within user polygons calculated extracting sum utilisation distribution values within . corresponding total prey mass within user polygons proportion consumption within polygons multiplied total prey mass. See worked example guidance implementation spmapper, retrieval visualisation results.

title: spmapper
text: Offshore wind energy central UK’s renewable energy strategy projected expand substantially terms generation capacity, number area coverage offshore windfarms (OWFs). OWFs potential adverse impacts marine wildlife, including seabirds, travel forage offshore areas. Among possible impact mechanisms, OWFs may impact seabirds via displacement foraging habitat, , seabirds may avoid windfarms areas might otherwise forage. , displacement windfarms may correspond loss access prey foraging seabirds, energetic demographic consequences. breeding season—particular period breeding adults rearing chicks—energetically demanding time seabirds. Seabirds must acquire sufficient prey sustain energetic requirements, provisioning chicks fledging. Safeguarding breeding success important seabird population dynamics influences long-term resilience. —seabirds must forage areas centred breeding colony—understanding estimating potential impacts OWF-related displacement breeding season critical effective seabird conservation. possible observe foraging success sufficiently fine scales comprehensive spatial coverage empirically map seabird prey consumption, describe energetic value marine areas specific seabird species. address knowledge gap, developed spmapper, spatial planning tool indicate foraging value marine areas key seabird species breed coasts islands UK (Black-legged Kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda). spmapper underpinned seabird time-activity budget energetics data collated Black-legged kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda, published via NERC Environmental Information Data Centre (Leedham et al. 2025). spmapper written programming language R (R Core Team, 2017). Information cite spmapper included ‘cite’ section.

title: spmapper
text: spmapper spatial planning tool generates maps estimated seabird prey consumption chick-rearing seabirds three species. tool generates maps calculating mass fish prey taken breeding seabirds comprising UK & Ireland species network three seabird species, according species-specific behaviour, physiology, diet, demography population size; estimates spatial origin seabird prey removal according models marine space use (utilisation distributions, UDs). See ‘Methods’ page details. central function spmapper retrieve estimates absolute proportional quantities prey taken three focal species networks within areas interest user. words, aim tool indicate energetic foraging value marine areas seabirds terms prey consumption shelf-seas scale. primary application outputs includes comparison total prey consumption candidate areas offshore renewable developments, within areas protective conservation measures. outputs can used assist marine spatial planning purposes.

what: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: fn.tot.prey represents model calculates intake prey (kg) single breeding adult seabird across duration chick rearing, based set values describing physiology, ecology demography.

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
code: fn.tot.prey(   TB_foraging,   TB_flying,   TB_resting_sea,   TB_nest,   ER_foraging,   ER_flying,   ER_resting_sea,   ER_nest,   ER_warming_food,   chick_ER,   chicks_n,   BS_length,   init_mass,   mass_change,   tissue_en_dens,   energy_prey_conv,   assim_effic )

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: TB_foraging Time budget: foraging: % daily time-activity budget spent foraging     (unit: % time) TB_flying Time budget: flying: % daily time-activity budget spent flying    (unit: % time) TB_resting_sea Time budget: rest sea:    % daily time-activity budget spent resting sea    (unit:     % time) TB_nest Time budget: nest:    % daily time-activity budget spent nest    (unit:     % time) ER_foraging Energy requirements: foraging:     Energetic cost full day (24h) foraging    (unit:     kj/day) ER_flying Energy requirements: flying:    Energetic cost full day (24h) flying    (unit:     kj/day) ER_resting_sea Energy requirements: rest sea:    Energetic cost full day (24h) resting sea    (unit:     kj/day) ER_nest Energy requirements: nest:    Energetic cost full day (24h) nest    (unit:     kj/day) ER_warming_food Energy requirements: warming food:    Nominal energetic cost warming food per day    (unit:     kj/day) chick_ER Energy requirements: chick provisioning:    Daily energy needs chicks (.e. provisioned parent birds)    (unit:     kj/day) chicks_n Chicks per nest (breeding success):    Chicks fledged per nest, give seasonal chick provisioning requirements    (unit:     n) BS_length Chick-rearing duration: Duration chick rearing    (unit: days) init_mass Adult body mass:    Mass typical breeding adult    (unit:     g) mass_change Percent adult mass change:    Percentage change adult body mass breeding season    (unit:     % change) tissue_en_dens Adult tissue energy density    Energy density seabird body tissue (adult)    (unit:     kj/g) energy_prey_conv Prey energy density    Energy density prey diet, used convert energy intake prey mass    (unit:     kj/g) assim_effic Digestive assimilation efficiency    Proportion dietary prey energy assimilated adult seabirds    (unit:     proportion)

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: prey intake (kg) single breeding adult seabird duration chick-rearing; argument single numeric value output also single numeric value, arguments vectors vector length length input vector

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: function first calculates daily energy requirements adult seabird, sum : ) weighted average energetic costs core 4 activities (foraging, flight, resting sea, resting colony), according time relative daily time-budget allocation. ii) cost warming daily food load iii) adult's half share chick provisioning requirements, multiplied average number chicks per nest (breeding success) Daily energy requirements scaled duration chick-rearing. Next, energy intake corrected account energy sourced via metabolism body tissue (thus prey consumption; indicated adult body mass change seabird tissue energy density). Total energy energy intake converted prey mass intake according dietary prey energy density, correcting imperfect digestive assimilation. Note, species explicitly specified function, rather function applied set parameter values corresponding given species. Note: argument can either single numeric value vector, vector vectors must length

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
text: dataset contains random deviate samples Razorbill energetics & behavioural parameters, based 'Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper'. row represent set parameter values used prey consumption model.  See methods details.

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
code: RAZO_sampled_spmapper

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
text: data frame 60000 rows 17 variables: TB_nest double Time-activity budget: nest TB_flying double Time-activity budget: flight TB_resting_sea double Time-activity budget: rest--sea TB_foraging double Time-activity budget: foraging BS_length integer Number days chick-rearing ER_foraging double Energetic cost: foraging ER_flying double Energetic cost: flight ER_resting_sea double Energetic cost: rest sea ER_nest double Energetic cost: nest ER_warming_food double Energetic cost: warming food chicks_n double Number chicks chick_ER double Daily chick energetic requirement assim_effic double Digestive assimilation efficiency init_mass double Initial adult body mass mass_change double Breeding season change adult body mass tissue_en_dens double Adult seabird tissue energy density energy_prey_conv double Prey energy density

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
text: Randomly sampled deviates parameters 'Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper'. See methods details.

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: dataset contains information key behavioural physiological traits three focal species seabirds: Common guillemot Uria aalge; Razorbill Alca torda; Black-legged kittiwake Rissa tridactyla. data describe daily time allocation energetic costs core activities energetically important processes species traits. data used spmapper() function estimate mass prey taken individual breeding adult species. See Leedham et al. (2025) full details data sourcing.

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
code: Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: data frame 25 rows 4 variables: parameter Character Parameter name Guillemot Numeric Parameter value Guillemot Razorbill Numeric Parameter value Razorbill Kittiwake Numeric Parameter value Kittiwake

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: Published dataset: Leedham, O.; Searle, K.R.; Harris, M.P.; Newell, M.; Wanless, S.; Mobbs, D.C.; Butler, .; Daunt, F. (2025). Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake. NERC EDS Environmental Information Data Centre. https://doi.org/10.5285/07b1105a-4a14-47e3-b491-9af59be90aff

what: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: Produces prey consumption maps extracts prey mass values within user-specified spatial polygons. Returns list various inputs, intermediate quantities, prey consumption maps extraction totals.

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
code: spmapper(spname, fppolys, tooldir)

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: spname Species name: character string. Must "Guillemot", "Kittiwake" "Razorbill" fppolys Footprint(s): simple feature collection tooldir Path directory containing tool: character string.

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: list, elements: "spname" (species name), "energypars_base_est" (energetics parameters - estimates), "energypars_base_sim" (energetics parameters - simulations), "udmap" (utilisation distribution, raster), "popsize" (population size - number individual breeding adults), "fp_ud_overlap" (proportion UD within polygons/footprints), "onebird_prey_kg_est" (chick-rearing prey intake mass one bird - estimate), "onebird_prey_kg_sim" (chick-rearing prey intake mass one bird - simulations), "allbirds_prey_est" (prey intake mass birds - estimate),  "allbirds_prey_sim" (prey intake birds - simulations), "allbirds_prey_fp_est" (prey mass footprints - estimate),  "allbirds_prey_sim" (prey mass footprints - simulations), "prey_cons_map" (prey consumption map - raster)

what: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Plot prey consumption maps, user polygons overlaid (optional)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
code: spmapplot(rast, polyg = NULL)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: rast spatRaster raster object plotted (.e. prey consumption map) polyg optional sf object (.e. user polygons) overlay raster plot (default: NULL).

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Prey consumption map Western European country polygons (via rnaturalearth), (optional) user input polygons overlaid: ggplot
